stream_context.summary: Kaze implemented major engine optimizations by fixing the game's culling logic, then spent the bulk of the stream implementing a complex, animated star select screen designed by artist Biobak. This involved significant technical problem-solving. Finally, he began developing a new, intelligent death/respawn mechanic for falling into pits, notably using ChatGPT to generate a core algorithm.

development_findings.summary: Kaze estimates the project is over 70% complete, with about four and a half courses left to develop.
development_findings.quote: we're missing like four and a half courses so we're like over 70% done at this point

development_findings.summary: Kaze identified and fixed a fundamental flaw in the original Mario 64 culling logic, resulting in a 3-5% performance improvement and increasing the frame rate from ~44 to ~46 FPS.
development_findings.quote: they culled as if the field of view was 45 degrees when an edge currently was 60 degrees and then because they get it wrong they just multiplied it with a random number and added a hundred

development_findings.summary: To implement the complex star select screen, Kaze designed a flexible system where each animated element is controlled by its own render function rather than a static geo layout.
development_findings.quote: instead of having one geolayout per thing, we'll have one render function per thing and the render function is what decides the geolayout. That's what we'll do. That allows the most flexibility.

development_findings.summary: Kaze refactored the engine to integrate culling radius and shadow properties directly into game objects, which simplifies adding features like shadows to enemies, a task that was previously difficult.
A new respawn system was developed that saves the player's last position on a surface, but only if that position is a safe distance from any ledge. This avoids manual checkpoint placement.
While fixing text alignment issues, Kaze implemented his own, more accurate kerning system because he found the original game's text rendering was off-center.
development_findings.quote: I invented kerning, yes. I'm sorry, guys, but I did.

development_findings.summary: Kaze follows a "one button, one output" design philosophy for controls, intentionally avoiding complex shortcuts to ensure the game feels intuitive and not like a software tool.
development_findings.quote: i don't want to add any button combos to do stuff because like it starts to feel less like a game and more like a tool

development_findings.summary: Kaze proposed creating a decal system to add temporary effects like oil stains to Mario. This would work by rendering a second, transparent Mario model with the effect texture on top of the original.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shared a dark, pragmatic philosophy on not engaging with online haters, suggesting that because it's easy for a determined person to cause real-world harm, it's best not to provoke them.
context_findings.quote: You need to put some respect on other humans, because they can murder you. That's the only reason. They don't need to respect their opinions or their views or anything. They're all stupid, but they can murder you.

context_findings.summary: Kaze enthusiastically used ChatGPT to generate a complex geometric algorithm for his new respawn system, viewing it as a powerful tool that saved him a significant amount of development time.
context_findings.quote: You guys have no idea how hard that would have been to program by myself. And this is why I like chatgpd. Who has edge detection algorithms memorized?

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a strong opinion that C++ is fundamentally superior to visual scripting tools like Unreal's Blueprints for serious programming, comparing using Blueprints for an entire game to an absurdly inefficient task.
context_findings.quote: do you prefer C++ or blueprints that is like a mentally ill question holy shit... you can also drink a full soup with a shovel

key_stories.title: Fixing the Core Culling Engine
key_stories.summary: Kaze identified that the original Mario 64 culling logic was flawed, causing poor performance. By rewriting the logic to be mathematically correct and refactoring the engine, he achieved a significant 3-5% performance increase.
key_stories.challenge: The game's performance was limited by the original, flawed culling system in the Mario 64 engine, capping the framerate at around 44 FPS.
key_stories.process: Kaze analyzed the original engine's code, discovered it used incorrect values for its field-of-view calculations, and rewrote it. He also refactored how culling and shadow data was stored, moving it into the object itself to save RAM iterations.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully implemented a mathematically correct culling system, resulting in a 3-5% performance boost and a more flexible engine for adding features like shadows to all objects.
key_stories.key_quote: I reduced render time by like 5% almost... I went from like 44 FPS to 46 and I made my engine a lot easier to use.

key_stories.title: Implementing the Dynamic Star Select Screen
key_stories.summary: Kaze implemented a complex, animated star select screen designed by Biobak. The process was fraught with technical challenges requiring custom rendering code, asset loading fixes, and meticulous debugging to match the artist's vision.
key_stories.challenge: The team wanted to replace the game's default star select screen with a custom, fully animated version designed by Biobak, which was far more complex than the original.
key_stories.process: Kaze imported Biobak's model and began a trial-and-error process to position elements correctly. He created a new, flexible rendering system, debugged texture issues, solved a pop-in problem by creating a custom menu segment, and fixed a subtle timing bug that caused a seam in the scrolling background.
key_stories.outcome: After a lengthy and difficult process of coding, debugging, and fine-tuning, Kaze successfully implemented the dynamic star select screen, complete with a seamless scrolling background and a cinematic fly-in animation.
key_stories.key_quote: This might end up being a lot more work than I thought it would.

key_stories.title: The Intelligent Respawn System
key_stories.summary: To create a fair respawn system without manual checkpoints, Kaze devised a method to save the player's last position if it was a safe distance from a ledge. He notably used ChatGPT to generate the complex geometric code required, demonstrating a modern approach to solving classic programming problems.
key_stories.challenge: How to create a fair respawn system for death pits that doesn't rely on manually placed checkpoints, which are unsuitable for the game's more open level designs.
key_stories.process: After brainstorming ideas, Kaze decided to define a 'safe' spot as any point on a ground triangle that is a certain distance away from any of its edges. To implement this, he used ChatGPT to generate the necessary geometric calculation code. He then integrated this logic into the game, adding checks to disable it on moving platforms and refining the camera transition on death.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze developed an intelligent respawn system that automatically saves the player's last 'safe' position on solid ground. This created a dynamic checkpoint system without manual placement, and he successfully fine-tuned the death animation and camera behavior for a non-disorienting experience.
key_stories.key_quote: You guys have no idea how hard that would have been to program by myself. And this is why I like chatgpd.
